title: Second Conditional
description: Learn to talk about imaginary situations and their unlikely results.

rules.title: Second Conditional Structure
rules.explanation: Use the second conditional to talk about imaginary or unlikely situations in the present or future. Use past simple in the if-clause and would + base verb in the main clause.
rules.structure: If + past simple, would + base verb

examples.sentence: If I had more time, I would learn another language.
examples.translation: 시간이 더 있으면 다른 언어를 배울 텐데요.

examples.sentence: If she lived closer, we would see each other more often.
examples.translation: 그녀가 더 가까이 살면 더 자주 만날 텐데요.

examples.sentence: I would travel the world if I had enough money.
examples.translation: 돈이 충분하면 세계 여행을 할 텐데요.

rules.title: Were vs Was
rules.explanation: In formal English, use 'were' for all subjects with the second conditional. In informal speech, 'was' is also common with I/he/she/it.
rules.structure: If I/he/she were... (formal) | If I/he/she was... (informal)

examples.sentence: If I were you, I would take the job. (formal/advice)
examples.translation: 내가 너라면 그 일을 할 거야.

examples.sentence: If she were rich, she would donate to charity.
What would you do if you were in my situation?

rules.title: First vs Second Conditional
rules.explanation: First conditional = real/possible future. Second conditional = imaginary/unlikely situation.
rules.structure: First: If + present, will | Second: If + past, would

examples.sentence: If I have time tomorrow, I will help you. (possible)
If I had more time, I would help you. (imaginary)
If it rains, we'll stay home. (possible) vs If it rained every day, I would move. (imaginary)
examples.translation: 비가 오면 집에 있을 거예요. (가능) vs 매일 비가 오면 이사할 텐데요. (가상)

rules.title: Could/Might in Second Conditional
rules.explanation: Use 'could' or 'might' instead of 'would' to show possibility or ability in imaginary situations.
rules.structure: If + past simple, could/might + base verb

examples.sentence: If I had wings, I could fly anywhere.
examples.translation: 날개가 있으면 어디든 날아갈 수 있을 텐데요.

examples.sentence: If we left early, we might catch the first train.
examples.translation: 일찍 출발하면 첫 번째 기차를 탈 수도 있을 텐데요.

examples.sentence: She could get a better job if she spoke English.
examples.translation: 그녀가 영어를 하면 더 좋은 직장을 구할 수 있을 텐데요.

rules.title: Giving Advice with Second Conditional
rules.explanation: 'If I were you' is a common expression for giving advice. It suggests what you would do in someone else's situation.
rules.structure: If I were you, I would...

examples.sentence: If I were you, I would apply for that scholarship.
examples.translation: 내가 너라면 그 장학금에 지원할 거야.

examples.sentence: If I were you, I wouldn't worry so much.
examples.translation: 내가 너라면 그렇게 걱정하지 않을 거야.

examples.sentence: I would talk to her if I were you.

rules.title: Questions in Second Conditional
rules.explanation: Form questions by inverting 'would' and the subject, or by using 'What/Where/How would you...'
rules.structure: What would you do if...? / Would you... if...?

examples.sentence: What would you do if you won the lottery?
Would you move abroad if you had the chance?
Where would you live if you could choose anywhere?
examples.translation: 어디든 선택할 수 있다면 어디에 살겠어요?

exercises.question: If I _____ more money, I would buy a new car.
If she _____ (speak) Japanese, she could work in Tokyo.
I _____ travel more if I had more vacation days.
If I were you, I _____ (not/accept) that offer.
What would you do if you _____ the president?
If it _____ (not/rain) so much, we would go hiking more often.
She _____ apply for that job if she had the right qualifications.

exercises.original: I don't have time, so I can't help you.
exercises.answer: If I had time, I could help you.

exercises.question: If my friend _____ (live) closer, we would meet every week.
If I _____ you, I would study harder for the exam.
